f_use_period_absolute_date BOOLEAN, if true, then the report period is defined in the absolute dates period_absolute_start_date and period_absolute_end_date; if false, the report period is relative to the creation of the report, defined in the relative period settings
period_absolute_start_date TIMESTAMP, absolute start timestamp (with time) of the report period
period_absolute_end_date TIMESTAMP, absolute end timestamp (with time) of the report period
period_start_day_of_month NUMBER, 2
 if not null and period is relative, the report period is rounded to the given day of month. For example if it is 15 every report period will start at the 15th of a month.
period_start_day_of_week NUMBER, 1
 if not null and period is relative, the report period is rounded to the given day of week (SUNDAY=1, MONDAY=2, ..., SATURDAY=7). For example if it is 3 every report period will start at a wednesday.
period_start_minute_of_day NUMBER, 4
 if not null and period is relative, the report period is rounded to the given minute of a day. For example if it is 150 every report period will start at 2:30am.
period_start_offset_days NUMBER, 5
 if not null and period is relative, the given number of days will be added to the report creation date. In normal cases it will be either negative or zero. For example -3 would mean the report period starts three days before the report creation date.
period_start_offset_months NUMBER, 5
 if not null and period is relative, the given number of months will be added to the report creation date. In normal cases it will be either negative or zero. For example -5 would mean the report period starts five months before the report creation date.
period_interval_days NUMBER, 5
 if not null and period is relative it specifies the lenght of the period interval in days. That is, the period end time will be calculated by adding that number of days to the period start time.
period_interval_months NUMBER, 5
 if not null and period is relative it specifies the lenght of the period interval in months. That is, the period end time will be calculated by adding that number of months to the period start time.
period_timezone NUMBER, 3
 The timezone of the period. NOTE: The timeslot is stored as CET.
granularity VARCHAR, 10
 if not null and period is relative it specifies the length of the report segment in reports that show data segmented by time.
last_reportid NUMBER, 10
FK --> dom_report.last_reportid
the last generated report
recipient_email VARCHAR, 129
 the email address of the user receiving the report
optional_field_lo_bits NUMBER, 20
 low bits of the bitset defining which optional fields should be included in the report
optional_field_hi_bits NUMBER, 20
 high bits of the bitset defining which optional fields should be included in the report
category_attribute VARCHAR, 150
 attribute for categorized reports
no_of_total_values NUMBER, 5
 total no of values to calculate for this report
no_of_processed_values NUMBER, 5
 no of already processed values for this report
calculation_start_date TIMESTAMP, time when report calculation was started.
calculation_end_date TIMESTAMP, time when report calculation finished. if the report has not yet been calculated, or the calculation is currently in progress, this field is set to NULL.
last_error VARCHAR, 4000
 error message of last failure.
f_archived BOOLEAN, true if the report definition is archived.
origin VARCHAR, 200
 The origin of the currently processing Job. It is written during job processing and removed afterwards.
root_origin VARCHAR, 200
 The root origin of the currently processing Job. It is written during job processing and removed afterwards.

dom_sforce_tracking

Contains tracking information to be transfered to Salesforce. A process (currently implemented as system task: TransferTrackingDataTask) periodically marks records in this table, groups the records by customer, and starts a job (TransferTrackingDataJob) per customer which does the actual processing of the records. Each job deletes the records it processed.

dom_table_metadata

Describes the database schema tables and how the tables will be replicated to the standby database. Standby databases are a copy of the production database for emergency situations or planned switches. In SchemaReplicationValidatorTest.java schema will be validated if each table is correctly configured. Read below the settings for the replication field.


  • constraint: name:check_replication
    type:CHECK
  • constraint: name:check_partition_type
    type:CHECK
Column Definition Description
table_name VARCHAR, 120
pk_database_replication
PRIMARY KEY
 Name of the database table. All domeus-core tables should be listed here.
replication CHAR, 1
 Indication about the replication : 'y' - yes. The table will be replicated. The table should have a primary key field or unique index over not null columns. 'n' - no. Tables will be never replicated. Sample: dom_selection_result. A switch to standby will anyhow restart the application, so the data will be lost. 'o' - optional. Tables like archive tables will be replicated with a lower priority (they are not absolutely necessary to be recovered after a disaster). These tables do not require a primary key. 's' - switchover. Switchover tables will be replicated by admins only in case of a planned switch to the standby databases. We include here tables with a high traffic ( like dom_job_store ) or pre-processing tables. The advantage to list them here is to minimize the volume of data transferred during working hours. These tables must have primary key. If not, the table needs to be small and marked as 't' 't' - external transfer. Tables will not be replicated even when switching over, but will be transfered using external tools.
partition_type CHAR, 1
 Partition type of the table c -> "common" -> means it has no relation to dom_customer, it's common data for all customers; -> needs to be backed up in one go to a common backup directory; f -> "foreign key" -> it is related to dom_customer via a chain of foreign keys; -> for backup each row will be associated with a customer and backed up in a separate split file; -> resolving the associated customer for each row will be done using the extra information from fk_path field; x -> "extension table" -> it is related to dom_customer via the customerid in the table name; -> will be backed up in one go, but separated into the associated customer's split data; n -> "no backup" -> these are temporary tables which don't need to be backed up;
fk_path TEXT, foreign key paths * provides the extra information needed to connect the table to dom_customer via a chain of (existing or virtual) foreign keys; * only makes sense if patition_type is set to 'f'; * the syntax is: [[child_column[,...]:]parent_table(parent_column[,...])][; ...] * the child column list only needs to be specified if it is different than the referenced parent column list, skip if identical; Example: supergroupid:dom_group(groupid) * the last FK in a chain must be omitted, as it is implicitly always: customerid:dom_customer(customerid) * the consequence is that an empty fk_path is equivalent to having a customerid field connecting directly to dom_customer; * a table which is not directly connected to dom_customer via a customerid will have a non-empty fk_path, with possibly multiple FKs listed, forming a chain of references which finally leads to dom_customer via one or more intermediate parents; Example: dom_relateddata_col_meta(columnid); dom_relateddata_list_meta(listid) * the links in the FK chain between the consecutive intermediary tables does not necessarily have to be existing FKs in the DB, but should logically be equivalent to FKs;

dom_credential

Holds all the credential information in ecm. Credentials are encrypted Credintials types: phrase - simple type, which has only one credential information password - simple type, which has only one credential information to store password certificate - has 2 credential information: pubkey and fingerprint account - has 2 credential information: name and password The algorithm for the encryption: AES(Rijndael).


  • constraint: name:fk_credential_ref_customer
    references:
    in dom_customer.customerid for customerid,
    type:FOREIGN KEY
  • constraint: name:uni_dom_credential_shortname
    customerid, shortname, type:UNIQUE

    in dom_system_user.last_modifier for last_modifier,
    type:FOREIGN KEY

pk_credential
PRIMARY KEY
 unique identifier of the credential

FK --> dom_customer.customerid
references to customer
shortname VARCHAR, 100
 short name for the credential, which is like a placeholder and will be used in UI
type VARCHAR, 15
chk_credential_type
CHECK
 the type of the credential information * Phrase - phrase * Password - password * Certificate - certificate * Account - account * Cms_account - service endpoint: user, password, url * ftp_account - ftp endpoint: user, password, address * api_endpoint - api endpoint: user, password, url * token_cert_acc - token_cert endpoint: apiKey, userKey, token URL, Xpath * amazon_s3_account - aws access key, aws secret key * google_storage - json string
credential1 BYTE, encrypted credential information BLOB
credential2 VARCHAR, 32
 encrypted credential information.
credential3 VARCHAR, 256
 encrypted credential information.
description VARCHAR, 500
 description of the credential

archived BOOLEAN, indicating whether the credential entity is archived
last_modifier NUMBER, 10
FK --> dom_system_user.last_modifier
references the system user who modified credential as last
display_name VARCHAR, 100
 display name for the credential, for types: phrase, password, certificate, account and cms_account the same as short name
restricted BOOLEAN, indicating whether credential is restricted one
